awd_titl_txt: NNA Track 2: Collaborative Research: Interactions of environmental and land surface change, animals, infrastructure, and peoples of the Arctic
awd_abstract_narration:
Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) is one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. NNA projects address convergence scientific challenges in the rapidly changing Arctic. The Arctic research is needed to inform the economy, security and resilience of the Nation, the larger region and the globe. NNA empowers new research partnerships from local to international scales, diversifies the next generation of Arctic researchers, and integrates the co-production of knowledge. This award fulfills part of that aim.

This project will bring together earth system scientists, engineers, ecologists, and anthropologists to develop a plan to document and explain changes in ecosystems and their effects on the plants, animals, indigenous peoples, and industrial infrastructure of the Arctic region. It will emphasize interactions between these elements to help understand, inform, and plan for changes to come. Researchers will focus on the Yamal Peninsula, which presents a continuous gradation of habitat types from forest in the south to tundra in the north, a rich diversity of endemic and invasive plant and animal species, a large population of traditional peoples, and economically critical natural resources. Yamal serves as a small-scale and manageable model for the Arctic as a whole, wherein changes in climate and their effects on temperature, precipitation, landform, plants, animals, peoples, and infrastructure need to be understood and related to one another.  The project will contribute to the curriculum development for a collaborative, transdisciplinary online inter-institutional undergraduate and graduate course to train the next generation of scientists to take a holistic approach to problem solving. The team will directly engage Indigenous knowledge holders and other stakeholders throughout the research project. 
 

The project aims at developing a convergence research team to study the Yamal region as an ideal natural laboratory for transdisciplinary work to understand the complexity and adaptation of Arctic biotic and abiotic systems to climate change, and the feed-forward and feedback mechanisms modulating the co-evolution of human society and natural systems. The participants will focus on developing research ideas and approaches for testing the hypothesis that displacing Arctic systems from their historic state of dynamic equilibrium under changing environment stimulates further changes to abiotic, biotic, and socio-cultural elements, particularly when combined with the spread of industrial infrastructure, to increase the role of feed-forward and feedback mechanisms. Two transdisciplinary research "transects" will be considered as main determinants of the Arctic system with two contrasting scenarios: gradual warning and extreme weather events. Planned activities will include two workshops, monthly virtual conferences, international research capacity building, and a synthesis paper.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Navigating the New Arctic (NNA) Track-2, planning project aimed to build an international team of earth system scientists, engineers, ecologists, and anthropologists to develop a plan to document and explain changes in ecosystems and their effects on the plants, animals, indigenous peoples, and industrial infrastructure of the Arctic region. Through a series of online meetings, the team worked together to review expert knowledge in specific scientific fields and to outline interactions among the key elements of the Arctic systems of interest: abiotic, biotic, social, and built environment. The team aimed to overcome discipline language barriers and highlight key knowledge gaps in respective research fields. These efforts culminated with a five-day virtual workshop carried out in March 2020. The workshop facilitated the development of a systematic approach to transdisciplinary vision of the web of interactions in the Arctic (see the figure).  

 

Specifically, this project aimed to develop a convergence research approach to study the Yamal region of Western Siberia ? an ideal natural laboratory that presents a continuous gradation of habitat types from forest in the south to tundra in the north, a rich diversity of endemic and invasive plant and animal species, a large population of traditional peoples, and economically critical natural resources. Yamal was considered as a small-scale and manageable model for the Arctic as a whole, wherein changes in climate and their effects on temperature, precipitation, landform, plants, animals, peoples, and infrastructure need to be understood and related to one another.

 

Through this lens of viewing Yamal as a microcosm of the Arctic, project workshop activities resulted in four research threads aiming to address knowledge gaps in (1) how tall vegetation in tundra impacts landscape structure, biodiversity, and resource availability to animals and reindeer herders, as well as the strength of induced feedback mechanisms, conditioned on the presence of human activities;  (2) how changing snowpack seasonality and structure influence tundra food webs and animal population dynamics, and whether they alter decision-making by reindeer herding families, in local economies, and for resource and infrastructure management;  (3) how the growing built environment affects the reindeer herding system, herders? mobility, predator-prey relationships, as well as interactions and trade between industrial workers and indigenous people and perceptions of the environment by these groups;  (4) how the management of reindeer herding, the specifics of formal social institutions, and markets for reindeer products affect community resilience, indigenous traditions and practices, and landscape structure. The development of these research threads represents the main intellectual merit of this planning project activities. The threads provided a foundation for the subsequent efforts of the NNA Track-1 proposal development in which twelve research hypotheses were generated. The submission of the NNA Track-1 proposal and the ensuing award by the National Science Foundation underscore intellectual activities and outcomes of this project.

 

Broader impacts of this project included several key elements. An inter-institutional and interdisciplinary ?the Arctic Climate Change Forum? course team-taught by project investigators and other researchers across the US, western Europe, and the Siberian Arctic was developed and offered in Fall 2020. It introduced students to the impacts of climate change on the Arctic in the past, present, and future and used the Yamal Peninsula of Western Siberia as an example to help students understand how global warming and extreme weather influence high-latitude plants, animals, and traditional people. Work during virtual meetings and the development of Track-1 NNA proposal allowed the team to conceive and mature a collaborative synthesis paper. Using Yamal as a case study region, the manuscript calls for the necessity of holistic understanding of the coupled interactions across the Arctic systems. The team also developed media products targeted toward broad audiences: a film ?Cultures of Ice? tying together Arctic science and Michigan winter outdoor life was developed as a ?teach-out? activity for the 2020 Earth Day: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0YY7J5Uj56s.
